children.name: kph
children.definition: abbreviation for kilometres per hour ki-lô-mét/giờ

children.name: mph
children.definition: abbreviation for miles per hour: dặm, lý/ giờ
examples: My car won'tdo/gomore than 70 mph.
She was caught drivingat120 mph.

children.name: speed
children.definition: the rate at which sb/sth moves or travels:
examples: The truck was travellingat a speed of50 mph.
particles that travel at the speed of light.

children.name: increase your speed
examples: He increased his speed until he was running flat out.

children.name: gain/gather/pick up speed
children.definition: go faster
examples: The Mercedes was gradually picking up speed.

children.name: reach a speed
examples: The trains will reach speeds of 140 mph.

children.name: maintain a speed
children.definition: keep the same speed
examples: The aircraft is designed to maintain a steady speed.

children.name: reduce speed
children.definition: slow down deliberately
examples: She reduced speed as she approached the village.

children.name: lose speed
children.definition: slow down without wanting to
examples: The engine made a strange sound and we lost speed.

children.name: an average speed
examples: Our average speed was 88 mph.

children.name: a constant/steady speed
examples: The disc revolves at a constant speed.

children.name: a top/maximum speed
children.definition: the highest possible
examples: The car has a top speed of 132 mph.

children.name: wind speed
children.definition: the speed of the wind
examples: The average wind speed will be about 14 knots.

children.name: air speed
children.definition: the speed of a plane in relation to the air around it

children.name: at high/great speed
examples: The train was travelling at high speed.

children.name: at low/slow speed
examples: Even at low speed, an accident could mean serious injury for a child.

children.name: at full speed
children.definition: running, driving etc as fast as possible
examples: He ran past us at full speed.

children.name: at/with lightning speed
children.definition: very quickly
examples: He moved with his usual lightning speed.

children.name: at breakneck speed
children.definition: very quickly
examples: He drove away at breakneck speed.

children.name: a speed limit
examples: The speed limit is 40 mph here.

children.name: a speed restriction
examples: New speed restrictions have been introduced.

children.name: a speed camera
children.definition: designed to photograph vehicles going too fast
examples: Most GPS systems will warn you when there are speed cameras.

children.name: the speed of light/soundthe rate at which light or sound travels
examples: The speed of light is 300 million metres per second.
These planes travel at twice the speed of sound.

children.name: pace
children.definition: the speed at which someone walks, runs, or moves
examples: pace of
You need to step up the pace of your exercises.
The pace of political change has been rapid.
at a brisk/steady/gentle etc pace
The soldiers were marching at a steady pace
at a leisurely paceat a slow comfortable speed
Lucy set off at a leisurely pace back to the hotel.
We climbed at a leisurely pace, stopping occasionally to enjoy the view.
Hequickenedhispace, longing to be home.
Traffic slowed to awalking pace.

children.name: velocity
children.definition: the speed at which sb/sth moves in a particular direction - use this especially in technical contexts: vận tốc
examples: This instrument is used for measuring wind velocity.
velocity of
an experiment to try to predict the velocity of a moving object
the velocity of light
high velocity
a beam of high velocity electrons
The speedboatreachedavelocityof 120 mph.

children.name: momentum
children.definition: the force that makes a moving object keep moving: xung lượng, động lượng
examples: We are trying to measure the position and momentum of an electron as accurately as possible.

children.name: gain/gather momentummove faster
examples: As the slope got steeper, the sled gathered momentum.

children.name: lose momentummove slower
examples: The ball was moving along, slowly losing momentum on the bumpy ground.
Once you push it, it keeps goingunderits own momentum.

children.name: how fast
children.definition: RegisterIn everyday English, people usually talk abouthowfastsomething or someone is rather than using the nounspeed:
examples: What speedwas he going?➔How fastwas he going?

children.name: how fast sth happens or is done
speed
children.definition: the rate at which sth happens or is done
examples: speed of
the speed of change within the industry
ahigh-speedcomputer
The population was growing at great speed.

children.name: pace
children.definition: the speed at which sth happens or is done: tốc độ, nhịp độ
examples: COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'in your own pace' or 'on your own pace'. Sayat your own pace.

children.name: rapid/fast
examples: The rapid pace of change creates uncertainty.

children.name: slow
examples: The pace of life in the countryside is slower.

children.name: a steady pace
examples: The economy was growing at a slow but steady pace.

children.name: at your own pace
children.definition: at the pace that suits you
examples: This allows each child to learn at his or her own pace.

children.name: at a snail’s pace
children.definition: very slowly
examples: Reform is proceeding at a snail’s pace.

children.name: a breakneck pace
children.definition: extremely fast
examples: Singapore prospered and modernized at a breakneck pace.

children.name: a hectic/frantic pace
children.definition: a very fast and hurried speed
examples: We worked at a hectic pace.

children.name: the pace quickens/accelerates
examples: The pace of change is quickening.

children.name: the pace slows/slackens
examples: After a surge in exports, the pace slackened considerably the following year.

children.name: gather pace
children.definition: happen more quickly
examples: Support for the campaign is gathering pace.

children.name: keep up the pace
children.definition: continue to do something or happen as quickly as before
examples: China's society is transforming but can it keep up the pace?

children.name: keep up with the pace
children.definition: do something as fast as something else is happening or being done
examples: It's essential that we constantly update our skills and keep up with the pace of change.

children.name: the pace of change
examples: The pace of change accelerated dramatically in the early 1980s.

children.name: the pace of life
examples: Here, the sun shines every day and the pace of life is slower.

children.name: the pace of development
examples: The pace of development in computer graphics is amazing.

children.name: the pace of reform
examples: Some senior party figures favor a slower pace of reform.

children.name: pace of
examples: The pace of change in our lives is becoming faster and faster.

children.name: at a steady/slow etc pace
examples: Public spending continues to rise at a steady pace.

children.name: rate
children.definition: how fast things happen, change, or develop over a period of time: tốc độ, nhịp độ
examples: rate of
The amount of light available will determine the plant’s rate of growth.
equipment that can load ships at a rate of 5000 tonnes a day
an attempt to slow down therate ofeconomicgrowth
at a faster/slower/different etc rate
Individual children develop physically and emotionally at different rates.
Children learn at different rates.
at an alarming ratevery fast
Our money was running out at an alarming rate.
Our money was running outat an alarming rate.
at a rate of sth
Iceland is getting wider at a rate of about 0.5 cm per year.

children.name: a faster/slower rate
examples: The urban population has grown at a faster rate than the rural population.

children.name: a rapid rate
examples: The plant’s ability to thrive in these conditions is partly due to its rapid rate of growth.

children.name: an alarming rate
examples: The alarming rate of increase in pollution levels has concerned environmentalists.

children.name: a tremendous/phenomenal rate
examples: He started to produce movies at a tremendous rate.

children.name: an unprecedented rate
children.definition: a rate that is faster than ever before
examples: We are losing species at an unprecedented rate.

children.name: a constant/steady rate
examples: The process takes place at a constant rate.

children.name: speed
children.definition: the quality of being fast: sự nhanh chóng, sự mau lẹ
examples: The women’s basketball team has talent, speed, and power.
I get a real thrill from speed.
He put on a sudden burst of speed.
with speed
She acted with speed and efficiency.
at speedBritish English (= very fast)
a van travelling at speed
Both cars were travellingatspeed when the accident happened.

children.name: miles per hour/metres per second etc
children.definition: use these expressions to say how fast sth moves
examples: ▪ The maximum speed on British motorways is 70 miles per hour.
▪ Sound travels through the air at about 340 metres per second.

children.name: ▪ a propeller that revolves at a rate of 150 revolutions per minute
